results.title: Production shot from Essie Coffey’s My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.brief_description: In the late 1970s, Essie Coffey’s My Survival as an Aboriginal used the documentary form as a political act of resistance. Almost 30 years later, Rachel Perkins’ documentary First Australians continued to correct history and create change.

results.title: Production shot from Backroads, New South Wales
results.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. While Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment, Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

group.title: Making Hades landscape in model shop

results.title: Production design in The Favourite
results.headline_credit: Ireland, United Kingdom and United States, 2018
results.brief_description: England, early 18th century. The close relationship between Queen Anne and Sarah Churchill is threatened by the arrival of Sarah’s cousin, Abigail Hill, resulting in a bitter rivalry between the two cousins to be the Queen’s favourite.

constellations_primary.name: The Hatfield House rules
constellations_primary.description: The shooting location of The Favourite, Hatfield House, has appeared in a number of other iconic works.

results.description:
When Australian production designer Fiona Crombie begins work, she asks herself what her design will say about the world of the film. In Yorgos Lanthimos’ award-winning The Favourite, that world is one of competition, intrigue and black comedy, with two rivals fighting for Queen Anne’s (Olivia Colman) influence and affection. 

Though the film is set among the grandeur of an early 18th-century royal court, Crombie didn’t want to overfill the frame. While transforming England’s historic Hatfield House, she stripped out paintings and furniture to leave room to focus on the characters. The details that were added weren’t always historically accurate, like birthday cakes and wheelchairs, but Crombie’s answer to her initial question was to have her design reflect the human heart of the film.
description_for_label:
When Australian production designer Fiona Crombie begins work, she asks herself what her design will say about the world of the film. In Yorgos Lanthimos’ award-winning The Favourite, that world is one of competition, intrigue and black comedy, with two rivals fighting for Queen Anne’s (Olivia Colman) influence and affection. 

Though the film is set among the grandeur of an early 18th-century royal court, Crombie didn’t want to overfill the frame. While transforming England’s historic Hatfield House, she stripped out paintings and furniture to leave room to focus on the characters. The details that were added weren’t always historically accurate, like birthday cakes and wheelchairs, but Crombie’s answer to her initial question was to have her design reflect the human heart of the film.

results.title: Prisoner production stills
results.brief_description: Prisoner packed a punch when it premiered in 1979. Set in the fictional suburb of Wentworth, the female-centred prison drama reverberated around the world, spawning international adaptations and a massive cult following.

results.title: Princess of the Blood Robes from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description:
A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
